metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Management of a COVID-19 patient in the endoscopy suite VideoGIE Journal CME Conflict of Interest: Disclosure and Attestation Article: Management of a COVID-19 Patient in the Endoscopy Suite

body_text.text: Since the COVID-19 pandemic started in December 2019, gastroenterologist have had to rapidly evolve their endoscopy practice to ensure safety of the endoscopy team members and their patients. Because the virus is transmitted via droplets and potentially via airborne inhalation of aerosolized particles, endoscopic procedures on patients with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 increase the risk of transmission to the providers.

To minimize the risk of exposing healthcare workers and patients, protocols and algorithms to reduce inadvertent transmission of the disease is critical. In this article, we review the workflow that was developed by the coordinated efforts between the Department of Anesthesia and the Division of Gastroenterology at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston. For this workflow, patients with suspected COVID-19 and COVID-19-positive patients are treated the same and referred to as COVID-19 patients for this manuscript.

Given the risks of transmission of COVID-19 during endoscopic procedures, especially upper endoscopy, one should consider performing only those procedures that are emergent or urgent. 1 Emergent and/or urgent procedures are typically those that require a potentially immediate therapeutic intervention, or cases in which the procedure is necessary to make an immediate change in clinical management. If the indication fails to meet 1 of those 2 criteria, if it is safe to do so, one should consider delaying the procedure or using another nonendoscopic technique to aid in the diagnosis or treatment.

Because the protocols being instituted for safe endoscopy in COVID-19 patients are new, it is critical to develop flow diagrams, cognitive aids, and simulation models (Figs. 1 and 2). Often multiple plan-dostudy-act models are needed to develop the optimal process. Training with live simulation models of how the process should run is crucial to making sure that the endoscopy team understands the new protocols and can perform their tasks seamlessly.

When arriving at your facility, you should put on a new facemask. Additionally, it is advisable to change into a clean pair of scrubs and keep your home clothing unexposed to potential COVID-19. All work areas should be carefully disinfected with a product effective against SARS-CoV-2 (https://www.epa.gov/pesticide-registration/list-n-disinfectants-use-against-sars-cov-2). One should consider repeated cleaning of the work area on a regular basis throughout the day. Even when wearing a facemask, one should maintain physical distancing in workroom areas and attempt to keep individuals as far apart as possible.
body_text.section: On arrival to the endoscopy unit

body_text.text: To reduce the risk and time of exposure of healthcare personnel to patients with COVID-19, consider obtaining all procedure consents verbally. This must be reviewed with one's local legal and compliance officers before instituting.

To reduce the risk of exposure to droplets from COVID-19, a negative pressure endoscopy room is preferred. If a negative pressure room is not available, then HEPA filters should be used. Ideally, all nonessential equipment should be removed. 1 Any equipment essential to the procedure or nonessential equipment that cannot be moved should be covered in clear plastic drapes to minimize potential contamination of the equipment. Equipment should be stored outside the room and communications (eg, walkie-talkie) should be set up so that individuals in the room can contact the "runners" outside the room to prepare any necessary equipment. Once equipment is brought into the endoscopy room, it should be discarded, even if unopened. Alternatively, equipment can be kept in a double bag and then, if not used, one can discard the outer bag only.
Additionally, one should consider intubation for all endoscopic procedures (especially upper endoscopic procedures) to reduce the risk of droplet exposures.
Proper signage should be placed on the endoscopy room door indicating that an aerosol-generating procedure is being performed and not to enter the room.
Consider marking a large square immediately outside the room as a buffer zone and an area to doff personal protective equipment (PPE).

Before starting the procedure, all team members should huddle to review the planned procedure. The huddle should be done in person with physical distancing or virtually. Each team member should identify themselves and their role (eg, endoscopist, anesthesiologist, nurse, technician, runner, etc). A safety officer should be identified whose job is to ensure proper donning and doffing of PPE and to monitor the outside door to the endoscopy room to make sure no one enters the room without proper PPE. Discussions during the huddle should include the following: which personnel will be in the room versus outside the room, what procedure is planned and any equipment that will be needed in the room or prepared outside the room, patient disposition, and whether any additional resources are needed (eg, environment services). Finally, one should check whether any team members have questions or concerns.
PPE is only effective if donned properly. The safety office should monitor the process carefully and stop the donning process if any concerns are noted. The key steps to proper donning are:

1. Remove all nonessential/personal equipment. 2. Perform hand hygiene: wash your hands with soap and water or hospital-approved hand sanitizer. 3. Apply head cover. 4. Apply N-95 respirator and ensure adequate seal. 5. Apply eye protection (or a secondary facemask with eye shield over the N-95 respirator). 6. Perform hand hygiene. 7. Apply shoe covers (option to apply leg covers, if available). 8. Don impermeable gown and secure. 9. Don 2 sets of gloves on each hand, ensuring wrists are covered.

COVID-19 patients should be brought directly into the procedure room wearing a surgical facemask. Shared spaces should be avoided. The procedure team should all be in full PPE when entering the room to speak to the patient.

A timeout should be performed and then all nonessential personnel should exit the room during the intubation to limit the number of people exposed during intubation. Outside the room, personnel should stand in the "buffer zone" and avoid touching the doors. Once intubation is complete, the nurse in the room can open the door, allowing re-entrance to the room. If equipment is needed, the nurse can call to a runner outside the room to prepare the equipment. Equipment can be prepacked in kits like a bleeding kit (sclerotherapy needle and endoclips). The nurse will then open the inner door when the equipment is ready and receive it from the runner outside. When inserting and removing instruments from the endoscope channel, turn the handle left and down to minimize potential exposures during this process. Additionally, using gauze to cover the instrument channel on removal may be helpful. Once the procedure is nearing completion, the endoscopist should advise the team that they are withdrawing the scope. Using gauze to cover the endoscope, suctioning secretions on withdrawal, and having the nurse cover the mouth with gauze are all advisable.

The provider's safety is the priority. Make sure that responders to CODE call must not enter the room unless appropriately donned. Management of an adverse event/CODE should proceed according to local protocols.
If an area is designated outside the room as the "buffer zone" or "doffing box," then PPE should be removed in this area.

After the procedure, the room should be left closed for 30 minutes to reduce any exposure to procedure-related droplets that might remain aerosolized. The room and endoscope can then be disinfected using routine typical hospital/institutional protocols for cleaning rooms and endoscopes. 2

To keep providers safe during endoscopic procedures in the COVID-19 pandemic, it is critical that protocols are developed to maintain proper PPE and limit the risk of exposures. Simulations and flow diagrams are important tools to train staff on how to perform endoscopy safely.

BIBREF0.title: Remove shoe covers (and/or leg covers if present)

BIBREF1.title: Remove gown and gloves and then perform hand hygiene

BIBREF2.title: If wearing an eye shield, remove eye shield and perform hand hygiene

BIBREF3.title: Remove outer facemask and perform hand hygiene

BIBREF4.title: Remove N95 while leaning slightly forward and discard, perform hand hygiene

BIBREF5.title: Remove bouffant and perform hand hygiene

BIBREF6.title: Apply a clean facemask and perform hand hygiene
